resources.path: Urban and rural populations in the United States - US Census Bureau (2010).csv

fields.name: Urban population (US Census Bureau (2010))
fields.description: When the US Census Bureau first defined urban places in the 1880 and 1890 censuses, an urban place was one which had a minimum population of 4,000 to 8,000 people. This threshold rose to a population of 2,500 for the 1910 census, rising again to a population of 50,000 or more by the 1950 census.

fields.name: Rural population (US Census Bureau (2010))
fields.description:
When the US Census Bureau first defined urban places in the 1880 and 1890 censuses, an urban place was one which had a minimum population of 4,000 to 8,000 people. This threshold rose to a population of 2,500 for the 1910 census, rising again to a population of 50,000 or more by the 1950 census.

The rural population is defined as any population outside urban areas.

fields.name: Total population (US Census Bureau (2010))
fields.description: Summation of the urban and rural populations.

fields.name: Percentage of the population in urban areas (US Census Bureau (2010))
fields.description: Share of the total population who live in urban areas.

fields.name: Percentage of the population in rural areas (US Census Bureau (2010))
fields.description: Share of the total population who live in rural areas.
